GOVERNMENT'S POLICY
TOWARDS EXPATRIATES INTERVENING
IN LOCAL POLITICAL AFFAIRS
(Statement by the Prime Minister)


    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): Sir, I apologise to the Member for Anson for having been absent from the Chamber yesterday at 2.30 p.m. but I have explained to him that my Personal Assistant was ill. There was an oversight.

    Sir, the Government's policy towards expatriates intervening in local political affairs was considered and stated on the occasion when a Professor of the University of Malaya inadvertently wandered into the field of political controversy.

    In the case referred to by the Member for Anson, I have received a long letter from the lawyer concerned and another from his client. The lawyer explained that the offending statement attributed to him in the Press was, in fact, a Press news item and not a statement by him. The point that non-citizens should not enter the political arena which includes trade union disputes - particularly where the Communist-controlled unions are involved - has already been made and understood.

    Briefly, we have stated that Government does not approve of non-citizens interfering with local political affairs. The Government would strongly urge non-citizens who are British European expatriates to stay out of the local political arena and let none of their acts, either intentionally or otherwise, be construed as intervening in local political matters. This principle applies to a man whether he is a Professor at the University, a lawyer in the profession or merchant in commerce.

Column: 1632



    Mr David Marshall: Sir, I would like to ask the Prime Minister whether he is conscious that a man in the exercise of his professional duties has often to accept instructions and to pursue a line of action which may be deemed to have political implications. Does he then consider that because the person is an expatriate he should be precluded from exercising his profession in any fields where there might be political implications?

    The Prime Minister: Sir, the dividing line between being just the agent for an employer and being a participant is quite a clear one. A lawyer who issues a statement in the name of his client is only an agent and the client takes the consequences. I think the Member for Anson is aware - particularly in the case of Press statements - that no advocate and solicitor can issue statements in his personal capacity or in his firm's name, because that means, amongst other things, breaching the rules of etiquette with regard to advertising. Had this statement been attributed not to the lawyer but to the client, a completely different position would have arisen. He would have been a pure agent. But where, as in this particular case, the Press report stated that he as the lawyer had said so after he left the Ministry of Labour, obviously he did it in his capacity as the lawyer and not as the agent, then the Government drew certain inferences from it. As I have explained, he has in a very long letter elaborated on the circumstances of how the statement came to be reported and I have no intention of opening the matter unless he wishes to do so publicly.

    Mr David Marshall: If it please you, Mr Speaker. Sir,I would like it to be clearly understood that I am not here at his request nor have I had any communication from him. But the statement made by the Prime Minister does raise anxiety from this point of view. He said that British expatriates should not intentionally or otherwise conduct themselves in a manner which may be deemed to interfere in our local politics. I would ask whether, in fact, the Prime Minister

Column: 1633

intends that to be a statement of Government policy and that if these expatriates do inadvertently so conduct themselves that they are deemed to interfere in our local politics they are to believe that the Sword of Damocles will then fall.

    The Prime Minister: As I have stated in opening my statement, the matter was carefully considered as one of Government policy in the case of the Professor of the University of Malaya and the principle was clearly enunicated - intended seriously and put across seriously

    - and the line of demarcation between pursuing one's profession and one's academic freedom in the University and meddling in local affairs has been made and has been understood. From time to time, those who transgress will have to be reminded of the policy of the Government. If it is a pure and accidental transgression, surely the Government will not be unreasonable; but if it is persistently repeated, then the Government must sit up and take note of it.

    Mr S. T. Bani (Thomson): Sir, I would like to ask the Prime Minister whether he would consider publishing the letters to which he referred.

    The Prime Minister: Sir, the letters were sent to me in my capacity as Prime Minister in the case of the employer. I am speaking now from recollection. I found them in my tray, having been opened by my Secretary. I think they were marked 'confidential', but I have no objection really to asking the employer to publish them. The one from the lawyer was marked 'personal and confidential'. He is a man whom I have known for some time at the Bar. As I have said, I have no objection to his publishing that letter and my replying to it publicly. Sir, it is not for me to receive a letter marked 'personal and confidential' and to publish it. But if either the employer or the lawyer wishes to publish it and open the subject for a public debate, then I must be prepared to allow them to do so. In fact, I would not say I welcome it, nor would I say I do not welcome it. But if they take that step, then I enter into the open controversy. But I cannot publish a letter - particularly

Column: 1634

a long one - from a lawyer whom I met, in fact, quite accidentally at the Ipoh Airport. He had come down from Cameron Highlands and in a few minutes explained to me that it was all a misunderstanding and then set out in a long letter how the misunderstanding, in his view, arose. The long and short of it is that he said that it was a news report and not a statement by him. And there the matter rests.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock (Cairnhill): Sir, I wonder whether the Prime Minister means what he says. He says that non-citizens should not interfere in trade union matters of Singapore and also in local politics. He knows that there are a number of non-citizens who are very active in the trade union field. One non-citizen particularly named by him was alleged by him to be most active during the trouble with the school children.

    The Prime Minister: Sir, the most important principle in politics is basic realism. The person that the Member for Cairnhill has referred to but not named, I think, is Mr Fong Swee Suan. We have withheld his citizenship papers for reasons which I think are well known to Mr Fong Swee Suan, and I do not intend to publish them unless he insists on it. The case of Mr Fong Swee Suan and that of the lawyer concerned are a bit different. One is a British European expatriate who dropped into Singapore in the 1950's and wanted to make a living. He is staying here just to make a living. The other one is a person who came here from the Federation of Malaya, went to the Chinese High School and has since been somewhat active in Singapore. He has been involved in many of the events which had interested both the Member for Cairnhill when he was the Chief Minister and I since I became Prime Minister.

    But I would say that, on principle, I fully agree that it is inadvisable for any non-citizen to be involved in political matters. It is not for me to say how circumstances may develop in which it would be very unwise for non-citizens to be so involved, be they expatriates of European, Indian or Ceylonese origin, or even of other origin nearer home, but

Column: 1635

perhaps obviously they feel that the time has not yet come and it is really left to future events to see when the time will come.

    Mr David Marshall: I have another question, Sir. Is the Prime Minister not aware that the President of the Chamber of Commerce, which arrogates to itself the name "Singapore Chamber", has stated publicly that he supports the Government on the merger issue? Has he taken this matter up with the President?

    The Prime Minister: Sir, I cannot tell the Member for Anson how deeply the Government feels every time a European opens his mouth in support of the Government. On many occasions, I have not only told the Chamber of Commerce but also even higher dignitaries - people with more influence in matters of commerce, finance and other things - to stay out, whether they are for or against the Government. If they come in and they are against the Government, then we will deal with them. If they come in and they are for the Government, then they are giving a stick to the Government's opponents to deal harshly with the Government.

    I am deeply indebted to the Member for Anson for bringing this point up publicly, because I would publicly like to disavow any support from any European or expatriate quarter for the Government. I say this unashamedly that those who wish us well and are non-citizens do best by keeping quiet and praying silently that the country will go

Column: 1636

on peacefully and prosperously. Those who are against the Government and open their big mouths may find a lot of unpleasant consequences.

REPORT ON WATER SITUATION
(Statement by the Prime Minister)


2.42 p.m.

    The Prime Minister: Sir, I had promised earlier that I would try to review the water position as soon as it could be reconsidered and the question of rationing. I would like to give the House an interim report on the present water situation.

    The rainfall this year up to the end of November was only 60.09 inches as against the average over the last 86 years for the same months of January to November of 85.24 inches. In other words, we are already short by 25 inches this year. Even if we get average rainfall in December, we shall be far short of the average rainfall which, over 86 years, has been 95.7 inches per year.

    I have here, Sir, the table of comparative monthly rainfall* in inches - the average as against the months January to November 1961 - and I will table this for the information of Members.

    In other words, the present stocks are only 42 per cent of the full capacity.

    The normal consumption of water in Singapore, which includes Johore Bahru, Sir, which we supply, is approximately 70 million gallons per day, of which about 40 million gallons come from the Tebrau River, and does not directly affect our stocks, whilst 30 million gallons is drawn directly from reservoirs either in Singapore or Johore.

    With inadequate rainfall this year, the rate of withdrawal from our stocks has created a deteriorating situation in which it has been necessary to impose rationing in order to conserve the balance of water stocks as best we can. By the rationing, we have been able to reduce from 30 million gallons per day to 20 million gallons per day, the amount we draw from the reservoirs.

    Every year over the rainy months of November, December, and January, the reservoirs are normally filled up to total capacity. Well, November is now past, Sir, and I may just read the November figures - November, normally 9.89 inches, but this year it was only 8.65; 1.24 inches short. But it is our expectation that over the months of December and January, the shortage of 3,400 million gallons will be made up.

    I have been advised that it would be imprudent to lift rationing altogether until we are quite sure that the Northeast monsoon for December and January will be wet, not only in North Malaya but also over South Johore and Singapore. As soon as indications are that the monsoon is wet and there is a fair expectation that the reservoirs will be filled up by the end of the monsoon period of January, water rationing will be lifted.

    Mr Bani: Sir, in view of the public concern and talk about this matter, which I am sure is quite unpleasant to the Government, would the Prime Minister clarify whether the political pressure in Singapore has anything to do with the variation in water pressure?

    Mr Speaker: That is completely out of order. Let us not have frivolities but serious statements.

    The Prime Minister: Sir, -

    Mr Speaker: I have ruled that question out of order.

    The Prime Minister: You have ruled it out of order, but if I may, Mr Speaker, Sir, you are fully aware that the question having been asked, I cannot hide behind the Speaker's ruling publicly.

    Mr Speaker: Very briefly then.

    The Prime Minister: Very briefly, Sir. The fact that the Communists should find that not only the nationalists but also the gods are against them is not something for which they can blame the P.A.P. But I can assure the Member for Thomson - whose friend, Dominic Puthucheary, tells me that he often misses his bath as a result of the water rationing - that it is not because of the Tunku or because of the P.A.P. that he had been somewhat more stuffy than usual when I saw him in the C.P.A. Room.

    Mr A. P. Rajah (Farrer Park): Sir, am I right in assuming from the Prime Minister's statement that the earliest day on which we can expect water rationing to be lifted is sometime in February 1962?

    The Prime Minister: Sir, I do not think that is the impression I want to create. I would have liked, as I have indicated earlier, to be able in the course of the debate to say that stocks are so improving that, we could lift water rationing immediately. But unfortunately November, which is normally a wet month giving 9.89 inches, has again this year been short by 1.24 inches. And if December and January again are short of the normal in this same way, I have been told that it would be most inadvisable to lift the rationing. But if in the course of December it is quite clear that we are going to have a wet December and a wet January, we might lift it by the end of December.

    Mr Lin You Eng (Moulmein)(In Mandarin): Just now we had an explanation by the Prime Minister of the water position. If there is plenty of rainfall and if there would not be any water next year -

    Mr Speaker: Order. I did not quite get that. I have not heard that at all. Perhaps the Prime Minister would assist by saying what the question was.

    The Prime Minister: I do not mean anything offensive if I say that it is just the Member's Hainanese accent which I find difficult to follow and which some of the Barisan Members also find difficult. Perhaps he could ask the question again slowly and I will try to follow, Sir.

    Mr Speaker: Will the Member please remember that this is a supplementary question - it must be a supplementary question - and no comments should be made which will raise a debate. It should be a serious question. Otherwise he will be ruled out of order. Mr Lin.

    Mr Lin You Eng(In Mandarin): I have one doubt here. If there is plenty of water at present but if next year there should not be any water, then we would have water rationing throughout the year then.

    The Prime Minister: I beg to reply in Mandarin to the Member for Moulmein.

    (In Mandarin): The question was not if there was no water next year. The question was that at present the reservoirs are short of water by some 58 per cent. With this shortage of 58 per cent, we must try to cover not by way of buying water but by the weather. If unfortunately the Russians should explode more nuclear bombs, then under such abnormal circumstances we would not have sufficient rain for December and January next year. We just could not help it. But if the Member for Moulmein has any suggestion to make at that time as to how we could get sufficient water for the people or to make water for the people, such as to make use of dry ice or to have artificial rain, then I shall be very grateful for his assistance.

FOR 1962

[Mr SPEAKER in the Chair]



2.58 p.m.

    The Chairman: Will the Minister signify the recommendation of the Yang di-Pertuan Negara before the Committee proceeds with the consideration of the Main Estimates and the Development Estimates?

    The Minister for Finance (Dr Goh Keng Swee): I so signify.

MAIN ESTIMATES, 1962



    The Chairman: We are on the Main Estimates. For the convenience of hon. Members, I intend taking the total for each head as it appears in the last column of the abstract of estimated expenditure for the year 1962 on pages 41 and 42 of Paper Cmd. 35 of 1961.

    We are dealing now with the Heads of Expenditure in respect of which amendments stand on the Order Paper.

3.00 p.m.

    Head 1 -

    Mr Rajah: Mr Speaker, Sir, I move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 1 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 4.*
*The same amendment stood in the name of Inche Mohamed Ali bin Alwi.


    Subhead 4, Mr Speaker, as it appears on page 50 of the Estimates, reads "Purchase of Official Presents . . . $500." This apparently is an entirely new item which has been introduced this year. I am not complaining about the amount, Mr Speaker, Sir. But what I wish to inquire of the Minister is, what is expected to be purchased out of the $500

Column: 1641

for the Yang di-Pertuan Negara or on his behalf? In this connection, perhaps I might throw this into focus better if, while discussing this item, I touch on the Prime Minister's vote. On page 6 of the Order Paper, I have an amendment standing in my name, "That the sum to be allocated for Head 7 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 7." I have personally no objection to these two heads as such. But what I wish to know is something about the comparative figures, and why it is more in the case of the Prime Minister than in the case of the Yang di-Pertuan Negara. Mr Speaker, Sir, if you will permit me to deal with both those items at the same time, perhaps it would be more convenient.

    The Chairman: It would be convenient.

    Mr Rajah: On page 74, Mr Speaker, Sir, there is an item under the title "Official Presentations . . . $1,500." Here again this is an entirely new item which appears in the next year's Estimates. Could I, therefore, ask the Minister why it is that $500 appears under the Yang di-Pertuan Nagara's vote and $1,500 under the Prime Minister's vote?

    The Prime Minister: Sir, I must first explain the normal procedure with regard to gifts. From time to time, the Head of State and the Ministers receive gifts from visiting dignitaries and other Ministers from foreign countries who pass through Singapore. Normal courtesy requires that there is reciprocity of these gifts. In the old days, Sir, what happened was that where they were personal gifts, that is, the gifts were to the person con, cerned, he kept it. When he reciprocated, he paid for it out of his own expenses. He kept the gift that was given to him, and he paid for the gift that was given to the visiting dignitary. In fact, the ruling since the Government took office is that all gifts presented to the Ministers or to the Head of State are surrendered to the Treasury. If they cannot be used, they are either disposed of by the Treasury or they are left in the Istana

Column: 1642

Negara, the State Guest House, or the reception rooms of the various Ministers.

    Mr David Marshall (Anson): On a point of clarification, Mr Speaker. I am not participating in the debate. But I would like to correct the suggestion that previously the ruling was that we could keep the gift. In so far as I am aware, at no time did any of the Ministers retain any gifts received officially from other Ministers or Government. They were all handed in to the Treasury.

    The Prime Minister: I think there was a distinction between the official and the non-official Ministers. The elected Ministers, as in the case of the former Chief Minister, the Member for Cairnhill, and his colleagues, paid out of their entertainment vote when they bought gifts in return. They surrendered their gifts to the Treasury. In the case of the other officials, I think the practice was that either they bought gifts in return out of their own emoluments and then kept the gifts, or they left the gifts in the Istana. As far as I know, either the gifts were kept in the Istana or left in the Treasury. Anyway, these are not very important things. What has happened is that for the last two years, when we reciprocated, we paid for it front the entertainment vote. The Accountant-General queried this and said that this was not a proper vote for the reciprocity of gifts. Therefore, a modest sum has been entered for the Yang di-Pertuan Negara and for myself. It is more for myself because out of this vote come the gifts for all Ministers. That is the reason for the $1,500 for me as against the $500 for the Yang di-Pertuan Negara.

    The Chairman: The amendment is also in the name of Inche Mohd. Ali.

    Inche Mohd. Ali Bin Alwi (Kampong Kembangan)(In Malay): Mr Speaker, can the Prime Minister please clarify how many gifts have been received that need to be reciprocated officially? Could the Minister indicate what emblems were used on the gifts that were reciprocated?

    The Prime Minister: In Malay, Sir.

    The Chairman: Yes.

Column: 1643



    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew)(In Malay): Mr Speaker, Sir, this matter is not an easy one for me to explain, because the gifts received from Ministers from other States are those that we cannot really evaluate because some of them are antiques and are very costly. Indeed, like the gift from the Prime Minister of the Provisional Government of Algeria, it was a scimitar. We left that at Sri Temasek because many people go there and they would like to know whose gift it was. So it is difficult for us to evaluate the gifts. But because ours is a small State, when we reciprocate, the gifts are, if possible, those made in Malaya. They are produced by the Malay Arts and Crafts of Kuala Lumpur. I feel proud that we share the pride of Malaya in the achievements of their arts and crafts, especially those produced by the craftsmen in Trengganu and Kelantan. We hope that in future or in ten years' time, we wilt be able to give our own gifts in return is the form of art mementoes from the State of Singapore.

    The Chairman: The amendment to subhead 4 of Head 1 can be taken together with that to subhead 7 of Head 7 at page 74. Tun Lim and Inche Ahmad Jabri have also given notice of amendments to the Prime Minister's vote. Do they wish to speak? When we come to that item, there will be no motion moved. I am talking about the question of gifts. No further comment on that?

    Mr Rajah: Just one comment. The Prime Minister has indicated that some of these objects are objects of art, and perhaps they are not able to be valued. In those circumstances, would the Government consider donating them to the National Museum? Where it is possible to evaluate them in terms of money, I take it there will be some Treasury control over the sale. Will the Minister for Finance assure the House that there is a corresponding entry in the income column for these sales?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Usually these gifts are collected and auctioned in public once a year. The proceeds appear somewhere in an item of revenue. I am not quite sure where.

Column: 1644



    The Prime Minister: May I say this? From time to time we do receive gifts. I do not want it to be indicated that it is not appreciated. I hope the debate will not take that line. But there are times when the gifts cannot be suitably displayed either in the Istana or the reception rooms of Ministers and Sri Temasek and so on. Then there is a surplus. But we do not want to give people the impression that we do not appreciate the thought behind the gifts.

    Mr Rajah: In view of the explanation, Mr Speaker, I beg leave to withdraw.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: I move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 1 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 8.

    This item is in respect of a vote for a motor car for the Yang di-Pertuan Negara. I would like to know what kind of motor car it is intended to purchase with this vote of $12,350 and for what use. Also, how many cars are there at present in the Istana Negara.

    The Prime Minister: The sum of $12,350 is for the purchase of a Rover car to replace the Rover car at present in use, which is approximately nine years old. As I understand it, the cars at the disposal of the Yang di-Pertuan Negara for his guests consist of one Rover car and one Number Pullman. There is no suitable alternative to the Humber Pullman, and the cast of maintenance is mounting year by year. I hope by next year we might be able to find a suitable alternative to replace the Humber Pullman.

    The Chairman: The Speaker's car is a Humber Pullman!

    The Prime Minister: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am told, that the garage has been complaining about the cost of maintenance. So it is in the case of Ministers and so on. There are two kinds of cars, as I understand it. One is for utility purposes and the other is where one has to go and present oneself for the occasion. I hope, Sir, when there is a suitable replacement for the Humber Pullman and the House feels in a sufficiently generous mood, we shall look after the Speaker also.
